conversation.content: What's your take on the proposed 25% medical equipment tariffs?

Ah, that's... that's going to hit us hard actually. Most of our adaptive equipment comes from overseas manufacturers, and, um, Medicare reimbursement rates won't adjust to match those increased costs.
How much are we talking per device?
[speeding up] Well, a basic powered wheelchair runs about $15,000 currently, so we're looking at, hmm, $3,750 increase just from the tariff, and that's before markup adjustments from distributors.
That seems unsustainable.

Absolutely. I mean, our clinic already struggles with the 80/20 Medicare split, and now we're essentially asking patients to cover an additional, uh, let's see... probably $4,500 out-of-pocket after everything.
[laugh hard] And I thought healthcare costs couldn't get worse!
Right? The irony is, um, domestic production for specialized OT equipment is basically nonexistent. We don't manufacture FES units or dynamic orthoses here anymore.
What about basic items like therapy putty or resistance bands?
Okay, so those are mostly from China and Taiwan. Even TheraBand, which sounds American, sources production overseas now. We're talking cents becoming dollars on high-volume consumables.
Any workarounds you're considering?

[furious] Honestly? We're having to ration equipment already! Like, we're literally telling stroke patients they might need to wait three months for proper positioning devices because insurance won't cover the new pricing!
Three months post-stroke is critical time lost.

Exactly. Neuroplasticity peaks in those first 90 days. Without proper adaptive equipment, we're, um, essentially sacrificing functional outcomes for cost management, which goes against everything we're trained for.
Are other clinics facing similar issues?
Mmm, yeah. The AOTA sent out guidelines suggesting we explore, uh, "creative billing solutions," which is basically code for fragmenting services to maximize reimbursement potential.
That sounds legally questionable.
Oh, it's a gray area for sure. We're talking about unbundling therapy codes, like billing 97530 and 97110 separately when they're really, um, part of the same intervention session.
What's the long-term impact on your profession?

[slowly] Well... I think we're going to see a lot of OTs leaving hospital settings for cash-pay private practice. The math just, mmm, doesn't work anymore when equipment costs exceed reimbursement caps by 40%.
